results.title: Private eye
results.creator_credit: Peter McKinley, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1970 film demonstrates the importance of eye safety and shows various methods of protection. The film opens with a sequence in film noir style of a ‘private eye’ working a case, with this gimmick interspersed throughout the film. It shows industrial working scenarios and various examples of eye protection, including safety glasses and helmets with visors.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry, Tasmania, and presented by Protector Sureguard.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Private Benjamin
results.creator_credit: Howard Zieff, Harvey Miller, Charles Shyer, Nancy Meyers and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Private Benjamin is a pampered upper-middle-class Judy Benjamin, widowed on her wedding night. She enlists for a three-year, all-expenses-paid sojourn in the U.S Army, or so she was informed by a persuasive recruiter while trying to decide what to do with her life. With such unrealistic expectations, the results can only be disastrously funny - and they are - in this now-classic tale of a fish-out-of-water coming of age via the rigors of basic training and European adventures that test her new independence.

results.title: Private and confidential
results.creator_credit: Joe Bogdanov and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: It was the first time a boy had kissed me. I felt as though I was reeling, soaring drowning-all at once, I gave myself completely to his lips! So thinks the teenage heroine of this in-depth look at True Romance Comix. The stage is set for Joan’s undoing. Useful for exploring popular culture, sexism and melodrama. Winner, Diploma of Merit, Melbourne Film Festival, 1984.

results.title: Privacy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The State of the Nation Bounds of Freedom”.
A journalist comes across certain documents which could be embarrassing - or worse - to a public figure. Should he disclose the contents of these papers? Moderated by Arthur Miller.

results.title: Prisoners of propaganda
results.brief_description: In 1943, the Imperial Japanese Army Secret Service forced a group of Australian servicemen to appear in a film to show the “exemplary” conditions under which Prisoners of War were treated by Japan. This program looks at the mysterious story behind that film, titled, Calling Australia.

results.title: Prisoners of incest
results.brief_description: Through the re-enactment, by actors, of a family group therapy session, this program documents the family trauma of incest. Members of the family meet together with a psychiatrist and a social worker to try and sort out their emotional reactions to their problem.

results.title: Prisoners of debt: inside the global banking crisis
results.creator_credit: Robert Collison, Peter Raymont, John Kramer, John Spotton and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This fast-paced documentary tells the inside story of how Bank of Montreal chairman William Mulholland dealt with his bank’s debt-laden customers, Dome Petroleum and Mexico, during the summer of 1982, the summer the global debt crisis took the world by surprise. Interwoven with the Bank of Montreal’s story are interviews with well-known international bankers and financial experts who explain the causes of the debt crisis, confirm the extreme fragility of the international banking system, and outline the problems to be solved if the system is to survive.
results.title_for_label: Prisoners of debt: inside the global banking crisis
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Collison, Peter Raymont, John Kramer, John Spotton and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Prisoners of Conscience
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Everyman”.
The case histories of Gustavo Westerkamp and Danylo Shumuk who were imprisoned for their religious and political beliefs are examined and the work of Amnesty International

results.title: Prisoners of chance
results.creator_credit: Thom Eberhardt, Marc Stirdivant, FilmFair Communications and Vitascope Productions
results.brief_description: Presents dramatized re-enactments of three case studies of teenage pregnancies: a girl who gives up her baby for adoption when she realizes she cannot cope; a girl who lives with her parents after the birth; and a couple who marries after the girl becomes pregnant. De-romanticises the notion of “Having a baby” by pointing out some commo problems of teenage pregnancies.
